Danger Mouse, show their nerve upfront in a mounting tension of acoustic guitar and painted-desert ambience, cut open by AuerbachÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s machete-treble twang and battered by CarneyÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s unhurried John Bonham-like rolls. When Auerbach finally gets to the chorus, he sings it as high-pitched warning (Ã¢â‚¬Å“DonÃ¢â‚¬â„¢t give yourself away/To the weight of loveÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½), lined with plenty of gospel-sisters heat.
In one sense, Ã¢â‚¬Å“Weight of LoveÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is the KeysÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ return to basics: a heavy blues. In every other way, that turmoil is a giant step into the best, most consistently gripping album the Keys have ever made. And that includes their 2010 smash, Brothers.

That LPÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s crunchy mix of Sixties soul and Midwest-garage glam was a rightful breakthrough. Turn Blue is a genuine turning point Ã¢â‚¬â€œ into a decisively original rock, with a deeper shade of blues. You still get the minimalist vigor of the KeysÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ first records a decade ago. But this is more brazen severity, richer and forward in its hip-hop allusions, super-size-rock dynamics, pictorial studio flourishes and offbeat commercial savvy. With its seething close-up bass runs and deathwatch vocal chorus, Ã¢â‚¬Å“In TimeÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is an aggressive update of Sly StoneÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s paranoia in ThereÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s a Riot GoinÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ On with a spaghetti-Western splash of Ennio Morricone. Ã¢â‚¬Å“FeverÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is a bizarre, knockout union of bar-band grease and Euro-disco concision Ã¢â‚¬â€œ Kraftwerk in gas-station overalls. The Keys have been working up to this since their first LP with Burton, 2008's Attack & Release. Turn Blue sounds like arrival.

Burton is practically a bandmate here, playing keyboards and co-writing all 11 songs (and co-producing all but two). He is also an expert magnifier and coloring agent, the likely hand behind the croaking electronics in Ã¢â‚¬Å“Turn BlueÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ and the fattened thwack in Ã¢â‚¬Å“Year in Review.Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ But the Keys are still a two-man band. Their strict, primary force binds and propels the extra textures as well as AuerbachÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s flinty verdicts on love always going wrong. Ã¢â‚¬Å“In Our PrimeÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ has less echo but more dirty guitar, curdled organ and a soul interlude with an orchestral hint of keyboards. Ã¢â‚¬Å“I see a face from way back when/And I explode,Ã¢â‚¬ï¿½ Auerbach sings before he and Carney blow up at the end. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s not Muddy WatersÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ lingo. ItÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s still blues.

Ã¢â‚¬Å“Gotta Get AwayÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ is an unexpected finish: straight-arrow rock with a hot chorus, the way the ClashÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Ã¢â‚¬Å“Train in VainÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½ was a hit-single exclamation point on London Calling. Turn Blue is as apocalyptic, in its way, as that Clash epic: loaded with risk, distress and payoff.
